import React from 'react'; import './LesionLens.css'; function LesionLens() { return (

The Problem

Melanoma is a malignant skin lesion with a substantial global impact, with incidence across the continents ranging from approximately 8,000 in Africa to 150,000 in Europe (World Health Organization, 2020). Early-stage melanomas, along with other malignant skin lesions, are often difficult to differentiate from benign lesions by visual examination alone, even for trained clinicians. Thus, diagnostic processes for skin lesions are inefficient, with unnecessary biopsy rates reaching up to 99.9% (International Skin Imaging Collaboration, n.d.), leading to higher healthcare costs and potentially exacerbating patient anxiety. Additionally, even in areas with access to dermatological care, patients face barriers such as high costs and long wait times. In the United States, the average out-of-pocket cost for an uninsured dermatology appointment is over $150, and wait times for consultations can extend up to 78 days (Walk-in Dermatology, n.d-a, n.d.-b). The health risks associated with delayed or missed melanoma diagnoses emphasize the need to improve visual diagnostic accuracy for skin lesions. The five-year survival rate of this skin cancer ranges from 99% for stage 1 to 30% for stage 4 melanoma (Healthline, 2023). Given the rapid growth of smartphones and mobile health solutions, there is a promising opportunity to enhance access to care through direct-to-consumer tele-consultation services for skin lesions. However, challenges remain, particularly regarding the inconsistent quality of patient-acquired images in telemedicine (International Skin Imaging Collaboration, n.d.). Thus, we are motivated to develop a low-cost, non-invasive, and efficient diagnostic tool for skin lesions.

Current diagnostic processes for skin lesions are also inefficient, with unnecessary biopsy rates as high as 99.9% (source for biopsy rate data), contributing to increased healthcare costs and patient anxiety. The health risks associated with delayed or missed melanoma diagnoses further underscore the urgency of improving skin lesion diagnosis. Given the rapid rise of smartphones and mobile health solutions, there is a significant opportunity to increase access to care through direct-to-consumer tele-consultation services for concerning lesions. However, challenges remain, particularly around the variable quality of patient-acquired images (source on telemedicine image quality issues).

Our Vision

Our vision is LesionLens, a free, proof-of-concept web application that provides near-instantaneous diagnostic support through a machine learning-powered model. In the “Model Details” tab, users can explore our model’s development, image processing pipeline, evaluation metrics, and other technical insights. We aim to deliver fast, accessible diagnostic support to individuals with skin lesion concerns, focusing on communities at high risk for malignant lesions, people who may avoid healthcare due to cost or convenience, and those who need quick, reliable information.

LesionLens distinguishes itself by catering directly to patients, allowing for use without the presence of a dermatologist or specialized imaging equipment. Our model’s accuracy, precision, and recall metrics are comparable to those achieved by dermatologists, as shown in the evaluation section of the “Model Details” tab (source for model comparison). To address quality issues common with patient-acquired images, we provide clear photo-taking instructions, advising users to use the best-quality camera available. Additionally, our model has been developed to handle image noise, lighting variations, and positioning inconsistencies, trained on tens of thousands of images with extensive augmentations to enhance robustness.

); } export default LesionLens;
